citeinfo.title: SF_Combined_Sewer
citeinfo.othercit: This database was created by William Lettis & Associates, Inc. for the Oakland Museum of California and the San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI), under a grant from the State Water Resources Control Board through CNPS Pollution Control Grant agreement No. 04-139-552-0 awarded to SFEI. Supplemental funding was provided by the City of San Francisco Public Utilities Commission, and San Mateo Countywide Water Pollution Prevention Program. Copies of the database can be obtained from the San Francisco Estuary Institute, Oakland, CA.

descript.abstract:
This shapefile details the major lines (> 24 inches in diameter) of the combined sewer system of the city of San Francisco, which takes combined wastewater and stormwater flows to the city's wastewater treatment plants. This system includes underground drains, tunnels, force mains, transport storage structures, and transport/storage tunnels.
This database was designed to help the general public and regional planners understand how water flows through San Francisco Peninsula watersheds.
descript.purpose: The purpose of this shapefile is to show the combined sewer system of the city of San Francisco. These digital GIS files represent the same lines as published on the Oakland Museum's Creek & watershed map series.

sngdate.caldate: The polygons in this digital database represent the most current data available at the time of data compilation. If users have concerns that these data are not up to date, they are encouraged to contact the local city government that has jurisdiction over the area in question.

idinfo.accconst: This work is public domain and we encourage the public to use the information openly and appropriately.
idinfo.useconst: These data were compiled at 1:24,000 scale and comprise a regional dataset. This dataset is not a substitute for a site-specific engineering study of surface hydrology.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.2.1350

citeinfo.origin: William Lettis & Associates, Inc. Author : Janet Sowers, Robert Givler, M. Teresa Ramirez-Herrera, Tillery, A., Richard, C.M., and Pearce, S.; Digital database prepared by Ranon Dulberg and Jason Holmberg.
citeinfo.title: Creek and Watershed Map of the San Francisco Peninsula: A Digital Database

attracc.attraccr: Attributes in this database identifies each combined sewer structure type and identifies all named stuctures.

horizpa.horizpar: All data should be considered approximate.

procstep.procdesc: This shapefile was created from Freehand files and imported into Arcview using a Freehand extension called Map Publisher. The shapefile was then registered to the Stateplane coordinate system using an Arcview Tool called Spatial Adjustment.These data were compiled at a scale of 1:24,000 and will be accurate at this scale. Use of this data at larger scales would be inappropriate as data may appear erroneous when enlarged.

srcinfo.srccontr: The combined sewer system was compiled from maps and GIS files obtained from the city of San Francisco Department of Public Works. It includes all major lines of the system, those underground sewers having a diameter of 24 inches or larger. A complete list of sources is provided in PeninsulaCreeksGIS_Readme_ver.1.1. Additional documentation can be obtained from Janet Sowers at William Lettis & Associates, Inc. in Walnut Creek, or at www.museumca.org/creeks/.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

edom.edomvd: Underground pipes that transmit under pressure combined sewage and storm flows in the City of San Francisco.
Large tunnels, bored through hills having a circular cross section. These store and transport combined sewage and storm flows in the city of San Francisco.
Large structures buried in the shallow subsurface having a rectangular cross section. These collect, store and transport combined sewage and storm flows in the City of San Francisco.
Tunnels that carry combined sewage and storm drainage, City of San Francisco. Tunnels bore through hills, carrying flows toward the treatment plants.
Underground pipes and culverts greater than 24 inches in diameter that carry combined sewage and storm drainage, City of San Francisco.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata
